Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2013 09:46PM luvmygoats wrote: Hey ladies - read this but very rarely respond.  One lady from our old group last year used very soft pieces of flannel under her rad breast to minimize that skin to skin contact.  She did very well.  I did sometimes use DH's hankies he never used.  Just threw them in a lingerie wash bag with bras.  I used Aquaphor, prescription cream (can't remember the name, made for radiation burns) and after tx used baby calendula cream from Target.  I did get a bit of a nip burn and used Domeboro soaks on it for a couple of days during the evening per RO. I have 3 tats but also had sharpie markings with sticky tabs for the weekly realignments. I bought cheap cami's and sports bras from Walmart.  Even the Aquaphor washed out well. Hope these suggestions help some.  Best of luck to all you ladies (and any guys that happen to be reading but not posting).

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2013 06:53PM luvmygoats wrote: JJ - I just keep my favorites tab open and refresh periodically. But Cindy is right about notifications/email. It might come off the Dashboard function. The box in upper L corner has it. Have you tried Aquaphor from the drugstore? Greasy but I learned to love it. I worked thru rads so had to wear a bra. I used a sports bra because the looser things rubbed more. The Aquaphor washed out very well; I still use the bras on occasion, none the worse for all the grease. I think I slept in a cami under my nightgown. I know I wore them under my scrubs. I thankfully had a female RO who was very sympathetic. Loved her. I had a weekly meet up with her and she or another RO was always available for consult as was the nurse. Cindy is right - the squeaky wheel gets the grease. Maybe the rads techs can advocate for you. Try on some phrases for size to use with your RO - like a practice run. I'm not so good at standing up for myself and find this helps tremendously. I've even written out talking points like a script - for myself of course. The more you say things the easier they get to say. Sounds like you're almost done. Do know that your symptoms will continue and may get worse up to 2 weeks post rads - at least that's the time I was quoted. Just like it takes time to build up it takes just as much time to go away. Not sure if they told you this and much better to know than think well OK, rads are done why the heck am I hurting/itching/etc. more.

Posts.Content: May 3, 2013 07:29PM luvmygoats wrote: I bought front closure Fruit of the Loom sports bras from WalMart. Those things are amazing. All the creams from rads just washed right out of them. I wore them 24 hours a day for months. Had no drains. Heard of pinning them to a lanyard. No tight bandaging either. Sent home in a very unsuitable bra provided by hospital. Thank goodness I'd already bought my own. I wore the sports bras to work not the most attractive look but then I wore scrubs. Had 2 "better" bras for church wear but went right home and put back on sports bras. Found the best way to put on front closure bras is to put them on like a vest. I would suggest putting a few of your dishes down low esp. if you will be alone during the day. I had trouble reaching up, even with good side but then I'm short. I got constipated and for goodness sakes I'm a nurse. I got DH to get me Senokot but Colace as Ruth suggests is great, too. Constipation is sneaky and by the time you realize you have it it well on its way to very uncomfortable. Yes, definite divot but I was happy did not have to back in to have margins redone. Divot has filled in underneath breast some with nice ugly stretch marks. Not so much on the side. I put small pillow under seatbelt on ride home but remember only bits of the ride. I did buy a sheepskin seat belt cover since mine on L side and still use. Button up front shirt and pull on pants. I still wear the flannel shirts I bought at Goodwill. I sat around for a couple of hours in pre-op little cubicle (tiniest room ever) and kept my pants and shoes on even to trips to nuclear med and for wire loc in mammo. dept. I did pack an overnight bag just in case per my BS instructions. SafiAnnie - time is the best healer for that SNB pain/creepy crawly feeling.

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2012 06:37PM luvmygoats wrote: Lettie - I would get that report as well as the final surgical path report.  Have seen some on here say they found differences.  I looked at my 2 today and they are essentially the same but each reported a little differently.  Used to be you had to drag reports/lab out of doctors.  They found out it was much smarter to give you your reports up front.  I wish I had the operative report just for the heck of it.  You might ask if the hospital has a breast health navigator or ask around to see if there is one at a close by hospital.  I don't think you need to be an active patient at the facility but I could be wrong about that.  If I had had much more done (chemo, mastectomy) I would have relied much more on her.  I get a comforting, cheery, encouraging email from her nearly every Friday. You will most likely be sleepy even without pain meds when you get home.  I don't remember much about the trip home (1 hour for me) or much about that night.  I could not pull the covers over me; DH had to do that.  If your daughter could stay with you or go to her house at least for 1 night I would think that would be good.  Then again I'm sure there are plenty of others who do go it alone from day one.  Slept OK.  Took my 1/2 Norco about twice/day for a few days.  I'm a wimp for pain.  I had no bandages or drains.  Surgical glue on both sites.  Some have steri strips.  Observe the site or bandages when you get the first chance.  That way you will know if there are any changes - that's the nurse in me. LE - you can get with just a few nodes removed but less likely.  My BS gave me no exercies or things forbidden to do.  I could not and would not raise my surg. arm over my head; too painful.  Had followup one week later.  I had driving restrictions for 2 weeks and I believe that is probably excessive.  I do drive all day for my job and was off nearly 3 weeks and then went back 1/2 time for a week. I'm a hospice nurse so see pts all around town.  She was concerned about my safety if I needed to make quick corrections.  You will have restrictions on how much you can lift, can't remember if 5#. Hope you have had a good day today.  Best of luck tomorrow.
Posts.Title: Overwhelmed Lettiegonz LittleMelons

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2012 08:31AM luvmygoats wrote: Lettiegonz - I second reading the pre-surgery list.  I only found BCO after my lumpectomy (LX) while on medical leave.  You probably will go home after surgery but my BS said to plan as if I had to stay overnight; I went home that afternoon.  Shop now for things that are easy to get on.  It will be hard to get things over your head.  I had surg. during winter so shopped for button up front flannel shirts.  Might be easier with stretchy summery tops.  Goodwill/thrift stores are my choice.  Go thru your closet and pretend you can't straighten out your surgical side arm. My BS (there is a list on the main BCO pages of abbreviations) had no particular recommendations about bras.  I bought front fasten sport bras (fruit of the loom) at Walmart and still wearing them.  Not the most flattering look as they smoosh everything but jiggle is still not comfortable (42-44D). It took a long time before I could fasten in back and still cannot wear any of my old bras as they hit right at SNB site. One thing I read only in a few places the blue dye will turn your chest blue and you will urinate blue for a day or 2.  Perfectly normal.  Some BS don't use the dye only the nuclear scan injection.  Mine used both.  Yes, the inj. for the scan hurt some.  Endurable, very short took my breath away but just for a second.  Read there is a numbing cream but some BS won't use it and I can't remember why.  I didn't know of such stuff so just went with what was done to me, not a rant just the way it occurred. Have things you might need placed low for you.  Get comfy perch on couch, recliner ready.  Stock up on things you like to eat/drink ahead of time.  No problem with appetite next day.  Surg. day I ate light.  Watch out for constipation esp. if taking pain meds..  Took me by surprise and I'm a nurse.  Over the counter laxatives.  Prunes, raisins, whole wheat foods, regular cook-kind oatmeal.   Go slow on sodas as gas adds to const. misery. I still have pain in site, but just finished radiation.  Take an occas. 1/2 Norco. My BS does not do frozen sections so she just took 3 nodes knowing I might face additional surg. if they were positive or if she didn't get clean margins 1st time.  My sono. showed no nodal enlargement so she thought there would be no involvment which there wasn't and got clean margins.  She got close on one side of the tumor but then made an additional cut which cleared it well.  Yours is pretty small, too, at 1 cm.  The size will prob. change with the final report so don't be surprised. Let us know how your surgery goes.  Read the pre-surgery list.  I think that list was for a mastectomy so very extensive and she was traveling to have it done.  But it will certainly give you plans.  AND it will give you something to occupy yourself with today.  I found my BS was not good at what we nurses call anticipatory guidance. About the type it will take a few days for the complete path report.  And yes get copies of everything.  Your path report is already partially filled in from your biopsy.  Your BS has that and, I'll say this gently, should have informed you of what he/she knows already.  I do know final DX can change as the surgical path report is much more detailed. Ask away.  I'll mark this as favorite and check back after church. TTYL I wish I had known about BCO before my surgery!

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2012 04:24PM luvmygoats wrote: Edi - Buttermilk Scalloped Potatoes.  Lightly oil 8x8" baking dish. Peel and slice thin 3 large russet (white) potatoes. Thin slice one onion. Boil both in large pot salted water just until barely tender about 5 minutes. Drain, rinse with cold water and set aside. Melt 3 TBS butter in saucepan. Stir in 3 TBS flour and cook stirring for 2 minutes until golden and well combined. Stir in 1 1/2 c warmed buttermilk and cook, stirring, until thickened 4-5 minutes.  Add salt and pepper to taste and I add a dash of ground nutmeg.  Dump drained potatoes/onion in baking dish and pour sauce over lifting potatoes so sauce goes in between.  Bake uncovered 325 degress 1 hours (I think mine took a little longer) or until lightly browned on top. This makes about 4 servings - I adapted it it was originally only for 2.  Potatoes are hard to size; I would rather have excess sauce than not enough. I sometimes put a little garlic salt in too and paprika on the top for pretty color.  I buy the tangiest buttermilk I can find. I could just eat these by themselves.

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2013 01:00PM luvmygoats wrote: Benny and Edi - The tats for rads are tiny needle prick kinds. I have 3: one in center of chest between tatas, and one on each outer ribcage. Used for the laser to line up exactly the same each time. I have read of some refusing tats. Then I had super sticky tabs that were repositioned occasionally. I had 6.5 weeks and every Monday had X-rays to check the positioning and that's when they would reposition the tabs. Somewhere on BCO is a great discussion of angles of rads. I only had from 2 angles so catch all the breast tissue one from the right, then it crossed over to the left since I had no positive nodes though was surpised that they did radiate the SNB site. I had the tats; at my age I don't think nude beaches are in my future and I wanted the best shot at rads since it can't be repeated on the same breast. I had some breakdown on nip but not extreme and worked through it all. I did not have what I would call serious breakdown. Did resort one time to Domeboro's soak to the nip. Rads b4 work and most in my office never knew when I went as I was done most mornings about the time my office opened. Only missed one early telephone call throughout. I know the Canadian protocol is I believe 16 sessions more intense but delivering ultimately the same dose. My RO said coloring (fair, red head) has less to do with SE than how the skin had been previously overbaked shall we say in tanning. Did warn me my sternum area which had seen the sun might be worse but wasn't.  Except for the extra time in my day and the fatigue which did happen as I progressed thru rads it was not that bad. I see other postings on here of bad reactions so sure know they do happen even with excellent ROs. I would add one thing to BE SURE OF - yes caps. When they do your preplanning make sure they get a position you can be at least minimally comfortable in. My rads even with the extra Mon. xrays were very quick but with more involvement esp. Benny you may have a longer time on the table. I had a good friend who was a few months ahead of me in tx. Her comment was very apt - it took longer to dress/undress than the rads, a little bit exaggerated but darn close. Hers had a card swipe check in which I thought was neat, not at mine though her center was newer. Mine had lockers, put stuff it, take the key with you. I always left purse in car, that's just me since I with my job you know driving around and going in nursing homes/pt homes all day it was already buried in my car trunk (Oh Edi I do know the English boot! LOL). I had mostly the same techs throughout even though the rads place was quite big, freestanding center. Females except for one trainee that I was asked if I minded him being there. Creams/lotions - I used a prescription that RO insisted on Xclair. Expensive even with my insurance. Also Aquaphor, OTC product. I see Glaxol, Biafine, My Girls and others mentioned on here. I also used as I finished up a Calendula baby cream from Target and still put on itchy skin areas. It smells heavenly. I had sports bras from WalMart since I was just coming from surgery. And still use those when I feel the smooshing/support need. Even the Aquaphor washed out of them. I did put on cami's to protect my scrubs and they survived. No lotions/potions 2 hours b4 rads; since mine were early am just what was left there from the night b4. RO wanted me to cream up during the day. IMPOSSIBLE and it worked OK. I might not have had the breakdown I had maybe - and a big maybe - if I had been able to but it was not possible with my job. I was lucky to find decent bathrooms much less nice ones with room to strip down. Edi - did you catch that shepherd??  My scones were OK. I'm eating them. The buttermilk was sooo thick that I had to add extra milk and they are crumbly. Eating them with a fork. Only had 1 tsp of sugar in them; I add more like 1 TBS and put I think what you call Demara sugar on the top. Isn't that the one that looks like crystals? Whew, I'm out of breath.  TTYL - must do some chores. Dog needs bath, too.

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2015 11:25AM luvmygoats wrote: CAMommy - I found underwire bras poked right into area of SNB. Still haven't tried them. I wanted less jiggly/bouncy all around so I wore lovely - not - sports bras from WallyWorld. I was wearing scrubs mostly and it was hot sticky so whatever made me comfy. I felt much better bound down. I had one nicer bra for church wear. Has the RO given you any cream suggestions for rads? Surely with your LX being so fresh he has some specifics and with Canadian protocol too. I will say that I wore cheap camis over my bra and even the Aquaphor I had to use washed out of everything. I put my bras in the lingerie washer bags with towels and they washed beautifully. Oh yes as labelle says "free boobing" when you can. I had some irritation under boob but most of mine was nip area. You'll want easy on/easy off stuff since most of your time will be dressing/undressing. Take a bag with your cream in it and put it on there. I had 7:30 rads and went on to work. I took a fanny pack with my cell, keys, creams into rads. We had tiny lockers for our stuff and the fanny pack or something similar helped to not lose stuff among bra/cami/scrub top.
